body:
Probably related to cryptography and static callbacks.
At least on one occasion I found that we had a bug - an still open socket / thread trying to read. Once pytest kills everything at the end of the test suite run, it triggers a double-free in openssl or something.

So it might be possible to fix this in our codebase by looking that one thread that is still doing something...
It does scare me a bit that we're still seeing issues like this related to Python3 just at the point where we're planning to switch entirely.

Backtrace from the core dump generated by this issue:

```
* thread #1: tid = 0x0000, 0x00007fff842e98ea libsystem_kernel.dylib`__kill + 10, stop reason = signal SIGSTOP
  * frame #0: 0x00007fff842e98ea libsystem_kernel.dylib`__kill + 10
    frame #1: 0x00007fff8afc852a libsystem_platform.dylib`_sigtramp + 26
    frame #2: 0x0000000105c84f61
    frame #3: 0x0000000105a3bc1a _openssl.cpython-35m-darwin.so`SSL_free + 49
    frame #4: 0x0000000105a8db7a _openssl.cpython-35m-darwin.so`_cffi_f_SSL_free + 138
    frame #5: 0x0000000103e61065 .Python`PyCFunction_Call + 276
    frame #6: 0x0000000103e28d46 .Python`PyObject_Call + 101
    frame #7: 0x0000000103e25e65 .Python`PyObject_CallFunctionObjArgs + 190
    frame #8: 0x0000000105c29ec6 _cffi_backend.cpython-35m-darwin.so`gcp_finalize + 54
    frame #9: 0x0000000103e58da8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #10: 0x0000000103e6e7c7 .Python`subtype_dealloc + 662
    frame #11: 0x0000000103e58da8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #12: 0x0000000103e6e7c7 .Python`subtype_dealloc + 662
    frame #13: 0x0000000103e58da8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #14: 0x0000000103e76ed3 .Python`subtype_clear + 145
    frame #15: 0x0000000103ef81eb .Python`collect + 1855
    frame #16: 0x0000000103ef7aa3 .Python`_PyGC_CollectNoFail + 43
    frame #17: 0x0000000103ed7b90 .Python`PyImport_Cleanup + 982
    frame #18: 0x0000000103ee184c .Python`Py_Finalize + 98
    frame #19: 0x0000000103ef7436 .Python`Py_Main + 3502
    frame #20: 0x0000000103e18e3f python`___lldb_unnamed_function1$$python + 224
    frame #21: 0x00007fff8d03f5ad libdyld.dylib`start + 1
```

@kriechi looks like your guess is in the right ballpark.

issue.title: Roll out synchronisation for mitmproxy tests

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
This extends some of the work I did for pathod and netlib to the mitmproxy test
suite. It also fixes what may be a leak in replays.

Fixes #1535

body:
as already reported via IRC a couple of days ago to the cryptography team
/cc @reaperhulk

I also have a PR in the works that improves test synchronisation in the mitmproxy portion of the test suite (#1543). This fixes the core dump on OSX and improves consistency across the board... but has some issues on Windows I haven't tracked down yet.

issue.title: Roll out synchronisation for mitmproxy tests

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
This extends some of the work I did for pathod and netlib to the mitmproxy test
suite. It also fixes what may be a leak in replays.

Failing on connection leak is disabled on Windows for the moment.

Fixes #1535

issue.title: OSX: core dump on exit

milestone.description: This will be the first Python3-only release.

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
##### Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Run mitmproxy console
2. Muck about with some flows - it's not clear if there's a specific triggering action
3. Exit mitmproxy
4. Observe that core has been dumped with the following error:

`illegal hardware instruction (core dumped)  mitmproxy`

The backtrace shows:

```
* thread #1: tid = 0x0000, 0x0000000110402f60, stop reason = signal SIGSTOP
  * frame #0: 0x0000000110402f60
    frame #1: 0x00000001101fa5a2 _openssl.abi3.so`SSL_free + 49
    frame #2: 0x000000011024b79a _openssl.abi3.so`_cffi_f_SSL_free + 138
    frame #3: 0x000000010f077065 .Python`PyCFunction_Call + 276
    frame #4: 0x000000010f03ed46 .Python`PyObject_Call + 101
    frame #5: 0x000000010f03be65 .Python`PyObject_CallFunctionObjArgs + 190
    frame #6: 0x00000001103e7d56 _cffi_backend.cpython-35m-darwin.so`gcp_finalize + 54
    frame #7: 0x000000010f06eda8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #8: 0x000000010f0847c7 .Python`subtype_dealloc + 662
    frame #9: 0x000000010f06eda8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #10: 0x000000010f0847c7 .Python`subtype_dealloc + 662
    frame #11: 0x000000010f06eda8 .Python`dict_dealloc + 120
    frame #12: 0x000000010f08ced3 .Python`subtype_clear + 145
    frame #13: 0x000000010f10e1eb .Python`collect + 1855
    frame #14: 0x000000010f10daa3 .Python`_PyGC_CollectNoFail + 43
    frame #15: 0x000000010f0edb90 .Python`PyImport_Cleanup + 982
    frame #16: 0x000000010f0f784c .Python`Py_Finalize + 98
    frame #17: 0x000000010f0f7dd7 .Python`Py_Exit + 13
    frame #18: 0x000000010f0fa34a .Python`handle_system_exit + 318
    frame #19: 0x000000010f0f9fc0 .Python`PyErr_PrintEx + 41
    frame #20: 0x000000010f0f9659 .Python`PyRun_SimpleFileExFlags + 908
    frame #21: 0x000000010f10d36d .Python`Py_Main + 3301
    frame #22: 0x000000010f030e3f python3.5`___lldb_unnamed_function1$$python3.5 + 224
    frame #23: 0x00007fffb9297255 libdyld.dylib`start + 1
```

---

Mitmproxy version: 0.19
Python version: 3.5.1
Platform: Darwin-16.0.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
SSL version: OpenSSL 1.0.2j  26 Sep 2016
Mac version: 10.12 ('', '', '') x86_64

issue.title: Disable static callbacks on Python 3.5 (refs #2970)

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body: As suggested in https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/2970#issuecomment-229367151, this PR disables static callbacks on Python 3.5+ to fix the `Cryptography_locking_cb()` errors.
